result.title: Objective
result.description: Objective: "To provide land users and managers with the enabling environment (policy, financial, institutional, capacity) for SLM adoption in the Kilimanjaro region and country-wide

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Extent of land under direct SLM in the project area and extent benefiting from upscaling

baseline.comment: Minimal land (14,398.00 ha) being managed in accordance with principles of SLM or integrated water and land management as follows: Moshi DC 2,500.00, Moshi MC 670, Same 200, Mwanga 53, Rombo 750, Hai 9975, and Siha 250

target.comment: Over 65,141 ha under direct SLM (project pilot area) and another 40,821 ha impacted by up-scaling in during the project\'s 4 yrs; an additional 1,000,000 benefit through upscaling of lessons through the National Dialogue and the SLM Investment Framework

actual.comment:
This indicator has exceeded (100%) its target in terms of land directly under SLM (74,532.59 out of the targeted 68,141.4 ha) in the project catchment areas is directly under SLM. Contribution by each administrative council is as follows: Moshi DC: 16,439.24 out of 13,000.00 ha under agro-forestry (2,200.00 ha), rehabilitation of gullies (1,000.00), actual terraces (7,551.00), land below terraces (150.00), land protected by cut-off drains (1,295.70), river bank protection (25.00), protection of water sources (35.20), apiaries (1,974.29), irrigation (89.05), sub-soiling (15.00), reforestation (2,104.00); Moshi MC 656.55 out of 1,000.00 ha under agro-forestry (47.30 ha), woodlots (15.00), rehabilitation of gullies (260.00), river bank protection (25.00), water sources (55.00), apiaries (250.00), irrigation (0.25), reforestation (4.00); Same 858.80 out of 700.00 ha under agro-forestry (150.00 ha), rehabilitation of gullies (100.00), actual terraces (97.80), below terraces (100.00), water harvesting (75.00), apiaries (155.00), irrigation (81.00), conservation agriculture (90.00), reforestation (10.00); Mwanga 37,734.00 out of 29,736.00 ha under woodlots (2,445.00 ha), actual terraces (19,516.00), below terraces (15,325.00), river bank protection (15.00), water sources (40.00), apiaries (30.00), irrigation (360.00), conservation agriculture (3.00) Rombo 3,263.00 out of 3,305.00 ha under agro-forestry (500.00 ha), woodlots (25.00), rehabilitation of gullies (30.00), actual terraces (1,000.00), below terraces (500.00), river bank protection (15.00), water sources (15.00) apiaries (25.00), poultry (3.00), and reforestation (150.00); Hai 13,598.00 out of 16,000.00 ha under agro-forestry (9,062.95 ha), woodlots (15.00), river bank protection (2,561.00), apiaries (1,063.00), irrigation (0.05), reforestation (896.00); and Siha 1,983.00 out of 1,400.00 ha under agro-forestry (800.00 ha), woodlots (1.00), actual terraces (643.00), below terraces (500.00) river bank protection (10.00) apiaries (3.00), irrigation (1.00), and conservation agriculture (25.00). Four districts, Siha, Same, Mwanga, and Moshi DC have exceeded their targets for land directly under SLM within the catchment areas. With respect to by upscaling, 26,978.00 ha of land have been impacted out of 40,821 (about 66%). The breakdown of data is as follows: Same District - 2000 ha; Mwanga District-157; Moshi Municipal Council-3500.00; Moshi District-2000; Rombo District-192; Siha 1129.0 ha, and Hai District-18000.00 ha. The reason for this low percentage in land impacted by upscaling is that the project experienced significant delays in its implementation. The drivers behind the late start of implementation are related to recruitment and administrative procedures, as well as the time needed to engage stakeholders and set-up the management structures. Activity implementation only commenced in 2012 instead of 2010. With such a delay, the project focussed more on achieving the primary target, i.e., land directly under SLM than on upscaling.
The reason for this low percentage in land impacted by upscaling is that the project experienced significant delays in its implementation. The drivers behind the late start of implementation are related to recruitment and administrative procedures, as well as the time needed to engage stakeholders and set-up the management structures. Activity implementation only commenced in 2012 instead of 2010. With such a delay, the project focussed more on achieving the primary target, i.e., land directly under SLM than on upscaling.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Reduction in soil erosion

baseline.comment:
More than 70% (924,600.30 ha) of land experiencing serious forms of erosion, with several erosion gulleys in zone 3
In 2005-06, minimum suspended sediment was 13.0-1132.3 tonnes/day.
No gully rehabilitated within the project catchments

actual.comment: The highest mean concentration of sediments as measured at the TPC (Tanzania Plantation Company) estate gauging station on Kikuletwa River within the Pangani River Basin in 2014 was 33.67 mg/l, compared to 1136.5 in 2006, resulting in a reduction of -1102.83 mg/l (>100%). Within the same period in the same basin, measurements at Ruvu River at Kifaru gauging station reveal that highest mean concentration (mg/l) was 24.33, compared to 42.8 in 2006, a reduction of -18.46 (43%). There over 100 gullies within the project area. Rehabilitating all of them was beyond the financial resources of the project considering that gully rehabilitation was only one of the hundred activities. As such, based on priorities by Ward Development Committees in the districts using gully size, and threat posed to properties, especially houses and cultivated land, each district (except Siha where there are no gullies) targeted to rehabilitate 2 gullies. To date, 6 gullies out of 12 have been rehabilitated, i.e., 50%. Two more are under rehabilitation, the rest will be rehabilitated before the end of the project. To date, through agro-forestry, woodlots, river bank protection, reforestation, etc., there is an improvement in ground cover by at least 60% (39,252.25 ha of the 65,141.00).

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Reduction in the rates of deforestation

baseline.comment: Currently estimated area of degraded land is 1.8% (23,026.04 ha in 2014) ; there are several seriously degraded patches of woodlands

target.comment: At least 25% recovery in highly degraded patches as measured by regeneration (recruitment) and improvements in species index for forests/woodlands and reduction in area of degraded land

actual.comment: No measurements of regeneration (recruitment) and improvements in species index for forests/woodlands and reduction in area of degraded land. However, as stated before, through agro-forestry, woodlots, and reforestation (18,425.25 ha), and with a recovery rate of survival is 80%, there is at least 67% reduction of the degraded land, i.e.,18,3425.25 out of 23,026.04 ha.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Carbon mitigated from energy switch and improved energy efficiencies

baseline.comment: Currently over 90% of energy needs in the region being met from wood, with minimal effort at improved efficiencies or energy switch.

target.comment: At least half a million tons of carbon dioxide mitigated by mid-term from institutional adoption of energy switch and improved energy efficiencies; and, a million cumulative at the end of the project

actual.comment: The project facilitated the design of a Project Identification Note (PIN) for a carbon-credit-earning scheme for public institutions, based on subsitituting biomass energy with methane generated form human waste, likely to be implemented through the UNDP Millennium Development Goal Carbon Initiative, and other carbon market schemes. The PIN was submitted to the Designated national Authority (NOA) for a Letter of No Objection to design a Project Document, which is the Division of Environment in the Vice President's Office in 2014, but the project still awaits the approval of the PIN by this department. This stalemate notwithstanding, the project identified 901 households that is providing with subsidized wood-saving or fuel-efficient stoves. The criteria used to select the beneficiaries included factors such as use of sustainable land-management techniques, e.g., soil and water conservation measures, agro-forestry, woodlots, bee-keeping, etc., and ability to contribute 20% of cost (TZS 300,000.00) of construction of the stove. In Moshi Municipality the stoves have been installed in 31 households. Firewood consumption per household before installation of fuel-efficient stoves was 7.3 tonnes annum, resulting in 13.3 tonnes of carbon dioxide being emitted. Introduction of wood-saving stoves led to substantive reduction in the use of firewood (3.6 tonnes per household per annum and emission of CO2 (6.5 tonnes per household per annum).

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Change in household wellbeing

baseline.comment: More than 75% of households below the UN defined poverty line

target.comment: At least 25% improvement in household welfare for a minimum of 50% of the households in pilot districts, as measured by percentage increase in household income, percentage reduction in number of food insecure days etc.

actual.comment: There is >100% increase on average in household income for households participating in SLM activities. In Rombo, it increased from TZS 600,000.00 per annum before to TZS 900,000 (50%) after; in Moshi DC it increased from TZS 365,000.00 pa before to TZS 1,460,000.00 (300%) after, and in Siha the increase is from TZS 480,000.00 to TZS 1,080,000.00 (125%). In Moshi MC, it increased from TZS 766,500.00 to 821,00.00 (7%). In Hai from TZS 912,000.00 to 1,168,000.00 (28%). In Mwanga, the increase is 200% from 500000 to TZS 1,500,000.00, and in Same by 100% from TZS 180,000.00 to 360,000.00. In terms of food insecure days, there is an average reduction of 43% from 95 to 53 days. In Rombo, the decline is 185 to 90 days, in Moshi DC 90 to 45, and in Siha 90 to 60. In Moshi MC, the reduction is from 60 to 40 days (33%). In Hai from 35 to 31 days (11%). In Mwanga from 120 to 90 days (25%), and in Same by 33% from 120 to 80 days. These changes have occurred because many farmers have now adopted SLM measures including conservation agriculture, on-farm rain water harvesting by sub-soiling, tree planting, production of improved coffee, production of improved fruits, soil erosion control by contour terracing. As reported earlier on, land under direct SLM in the districts is as follows: 15, 834.95 ha out of the target of 13,000.00 ha in Moshi District, 3,263.00 out of 3,305.00 ha in Rombo, 1,983.00 out of 1,480.00 in Siha. Household welfare has also increased significantly from increased productivity of crops for farmers taking up SLM practices advocated by the project. The regional average crop yield has improved for main crops such as banana from 24.3 to 38tonnes/ha, maize from 4.2 to 9.5 t/ha, and coffee from 0.5 to 1.1 t/ha amongst households that are participating in the project. Specifically, data from districts indicate that in Rombo, banana yield increased from 11.3 to 12.0 t/ha, and 0.6 to 1.0 t/ha of maize. In Moshi DC, banana yield improved from 10.0 to 14 t/ha, maize from 2.0 to 4.0 t/ha, and coffee from 0.1 to 0.8 t/ha. In Siha, banana yield changed from 3.0 to 12.0 t/ha, maize from 1.6 to 4.5 t/ha and coffee from 0.2 to 0.3 t/ha. With such increases in crop yields, its not surprising that the household well-being has changed for the better as a result of the project. On the other hand, crop yields amongst non-participating households have remained static, e.g., 24.3 tonnes of bananas per ha, 3.6 tonnes of maize/ha and 0.6 tonnes of coffee per ha.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Number of policies mainstreaming SLM

baseline.comment: All policy statements mention importance of SLM but don't have details of how SLM will be ensured

target.comment: At least 3 policies revised to mainstream SLM principles and so provide a better policy environment for SLM;

actual.comment: Policy Review is a lengthy process in the sense that once a need to review a policy has been identified, a brief is prepared for the relevant Ministry which approves it. Once approved, the review is commissioned. When the review process is concluded, the cabinet, and then parliament has to ratify the new policy or legislation. Given this lengthy process, it is unlikely that any policy or legislation can be ratified or amended respectively within the lifetime of this project. However, a study on Policy Review, harmonization, and traditional institutions in natural resources management was commissioned by the project. It had 3 phases, i.e., Phase I - Assessment, documentation and Publication on Indigenous Institutions and Knowledge in Natural Resource Management in Project Pilot Districts, Phase II- Assessment to which national policies are implemented on the ground, identifying pull and push factors influencing either implementation or lack thereof, and Phase III- Assessment of the extent to which productive sector policies mainstream Sustainable Land Management principles. This study resulted in 3 policy briefs, 1 for each phase. Specifically the study on Phase III reveals that 12 twelve sectoral policies that impinge upon natural resources management in the region were analysed to determine the extent to which they have mainstreamed SLM principles such as i) Improved land productivity; ii) Improved livelihoods; and iii) Improved ecosystems. The study revealed that only six (50%) sector policies have adequately mainstreamed the SLM principles. Five (42%) and one (8%) of the sector policies have moderately mainstreamed and slightly mainstreamed the principles. The study also revealed that the key challenge in mainstreaming of SLM principles is shortage of human and financial resources. As such, the study, and subsequently the policy brief for Phase III recommended that for effective mainstreaming of the SLM principles sufficient budgetary allocations are needed for effective implementation of SLM principles. For this to be achieved, there is need for political support to mainstream the SLM Principles into the pertinent policies. It would thus recommended be appropriate that there is concerted efforts by both NRM experts and politicians to ensure that the process of mainstreaming is successful. The brief has since been submitted to the Office of Vice President so that the recommendation is included in the Policy Review process of the Environmental Policy and Environmental which is underway. The Project is keenly following up on the policy briefs that have been submitted.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of policies with legislation and institutional arrangement for effective implementation

baseline.comment: Policy implementation very weak due to weak judiciary and inadequate understanding of, and buy-in for the policies form local communities

target.comment: At least 3 key policies revised to mainstream SLM principles and so provide a better policy environment for SLM; Legislation and institutional arrangement guiding policy implementation for at least 3 key policies are influenced by project results and overtly recognize SLM principles; Local level governance of SLM improved by incorporation of traditional regulations into bye laws with clear implementation mechanisms The National SLM Investment Strategy formulated and delivering additional finances for upscaling SLM

actual.comment: A study on Policy Review, harmonization, and traditional institutions in natural resources management was commissioned by the project. It had 3 phases, i.e., Phase I - Assessment, documentation and Publication on Indigenous Institutions and Knowledge in Natural Resource Management in Project Pilot Districts, Phase II- Assessment to which national policies are implemented on the ground, identifying pull and push factors influencing either implementation or lack thereof, and Phase III- Assessment of the extent to which productive sector policies mainstream Sustainable Land Management principles. This study resulted in 3 policy briefs, 1 for each phase. Specifically the study on Phase I recommends integration of traditional institutions and knowledge into the formal institutions and structures for effective implementation of SLM practices. As is the case with Phase III, the study came up with a policy brief that has numerous recommendations, two of which are as follows: i) it would be appropriate if policy makers could be actively involved in the promotion and integration of indigenous products such farm yard manure and compost into modernity. This recommendation will address the issue of modernity and reliance on market economy, which accounts for the low rate of use of indigenous practices while encouraging democratic governance that allows the majority decision to rule even in matters that have indigenously been managed through cultural norms and beliefs; and ii) there is a need for policy recognition of indigenous methods as part of superior ways in solving some of the problems facing land and natural resource management in general. Therefore, there is a need to establish a communication forum with the remaining traditional leaders that could empower them in sustainable land management. Just like the policy brief for Phase III, the brief for Phase I has been submitted to the Office of the Vice President.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Markets support expansion of livelihood options in Kilimanjaro to reduce pressure on agriculture and natural resources and increase income

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Percentage of cooking energy for institutions being met from alternatives

baseline.comment: Currently 100% of energy for cooking being met from wood

target.comment: At least 40% of energy for cooking in the public institutions being met from alternatives and the rest being derived in highly efficient systems

actual.comment:
As reported previously, the project commissioned a study on Fuel-efficient Technologies, which was undertaken by Mutimba. The findings of the Mutimba report can be accessed on http://www.kilimanjaro.go.tz/kurasa/habari_moto/hm3/index2.php. Phase II, of the study used the information to design a carbon finance project for public institutions based on the energy switch principle, in line with UNDPs MDG Carbon Finance pilots. Under this phase, the project facilitated the design of a Project Identification Note (PIN) for a carbon-credit-earning scheme for public institutions, based on subsitituting biomass energy with methane generated from human waste, likely to be implemented through the UNDP Millennium Development Goal Carbon Initiative, and other carbon market schemes. Phase II found that some institutions are better prepared than others to move to the next phase of the project, based on following criteria:
i) The type of cook stoves in use should be energy-saving
ii) Operation and maintenance of the stoves properly operated and serviced
iii) Physical condition of the stoves should be good
iv) Energy initiatives in place wood lot, solar, biogas.
While they may not have excelled in all the areas listed above, the following institutions did well in at least three of them.
i) Visitation secondary school
ii) Orkolili secondary school
iii) Tarakea secondary school
iv) Karanga Prison
v) The Police
vi) Kibosho hospital
The above institutions were recommended to benefit from the Carbon Finance Project. Again, as reported before, the project formulated a Project Idea Note (PIN), which was submitted to the Designated national Authority (NOA) for a Letter of No Objection to design a Project Document, which is the Division of Environment in the Vice President's Office in 2014, but the project still awaits the approval of the PIN by this department. Consequent upon this stalemate, there is no cooking energy for institutions being met from alternatives

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Amounts of money being earned by the public institutions from sale of carbon credits

baseline.comment: Currently none

target.comment: public institutions sell at least 500,000 to 1 million tonnes of carbon by end of the project

actual.comment: No carbon credits sold yet. Institutions need to be assisted to develop the carbon finance project, market it and implement the improved energy measures (replacing wood with methane generated from human and kitchen waste, replacing inefficient kilns and burners with more efficient ones, etc.), before carbon credits can be earned and sold. Greenhouse gases targeted are Methane (CH4) and Carbon dioxide (CO2). Type of activities of the envisaged project include installation of biogas digester and supporting infrastructure, installation of biogas cookers in place of biomass stoves, and training of kitchen staff in the operation and maintenance of the new cooking system. The designed PIN estimates that Up to a period of 10 years 52,387tCO2-equivalent would be sequestered. However, as reported above, the carbon project is still at the PIN stage. Without the approval of the PIN by the National Approving Authority, the project cannot be designed.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of farmers participating in shade coffee marketing and amounts of money earned

baseline.comment:
Shade coffee project reaching a small group of coffee farmers (less than 15%); Rombo 1312 farmers with (TZS 178.75 billion pa)
Siha District-2025 coffee farmers marketing their coffee as shade coffee out of 20,545 (9.8%) with TZS 30.79 billion pa, Moshi DC 15, 367 farmers earning TZS 1,746,00 000,000, Hai 10,519 farmers making TZS 7,700,000,000.00 pa, and Mwanga 439 farmers, making TZS 50,748,500.00

target.comment: At least 20% increase in the number of coffee farmers marketing their coffee as shade coffee

actual.comment: Regionally, there has been an increase of about 6% in the number of farmers that market their coffee as shade coffee, i.e., from 29,662 to 31,423 based on data from the 5 districts which grow coffee. By district, the numbers changed from 15,367 to 16,392 in Moshi DC, Siha (from 2,025 to 2,124), Mwanga 439 to 639, Rombo 1,312 to 1,749 while the number remained static in Hai at 10,519. This increase has led to a concomitant increase in the amount of money earned. Regionally, the increase is approximately 51.6% from 40,471,498, 500.00 to TZS 61,369, 832, 000.00. At district level, the increase is from TZS 7.7 to 8.5 billion in Hai, Moshi DC TZS 1.7 to 5.9 billion, Rombo TZS 178.7 to 440.0 billion, TZS 30.7 to 46.4 billion in Siha, and TZS 50.7 to 70.8 million in Mwanga. These achievements have been made especially because the project provided training to farmers in production of high quality coffee. The actual number of farmers is unlikely to reach the target because the drop in coffee prices has discouraged them from maintaining coffee production. However, it is hoped that with the increase in income generated by those farmers trained by the project more farmers will revert back to coffee cultivation and sell it as shade coffee. The other factor is that the project delayed to start implementing, which also affected this activity. The coffee trees that have just been planted after interventions by the project will take years 3 to 4 years, which is beyond this project's lifetime. The project, however, is againg confident that once the new plants start yielding coffee, farmers will be motivated to emualte the early adapters, hence the number of those producing and marketing their coffee as a specialty will increase.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Access to micro-finance and credits

baseline.comment: Less than 10% of farmers have access to micro-finance and credits. Siha 7849, Moshi MC 59 farmers, Hai 3376, Moshi DC 1,920, Rombo 696, Same 150.

target.comment: At least 25% increase in number of farmers accessing micro-finance and credit

actual.comment: There is an increase in the number of farmers accessing finance and credit >100%, i.e., from 14,050 to 24,291. A breakdown by district is given below as follows: Siha District- from 7,849 to 8,614 farmers, an increase of 9.7% Rombo District- 696 to 1,182 farmers (69.8%) Hai District- 3,376 to 12,575 (272%), Moshi DC 0% increase, Moshi MC from 59 to 259 (339%), Mwanga from 0 to 14,260, and Sae from 150 to 400 (167%). The project helped the farmers to establish viable enterprises, and supported them in formalization of different producer groups to the extent that they attained legal status. These are some of the conditions that must be fulfilled for user groups to access finance and credit services from financial institutions.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of new viable business as an avenue for energizing local economic development

baseline.comment: Limited opportunities for markets due to very few agro processing businesses, hence agricultural produce difficult to market

target.comment: At least 3 agri-processing business established and making contribution to local economic development and SLM

actual.comment: Three enterprises have been established so far, i.e., bee-keeping, poultry, and mushroom production. These enterprises are at various stages of development; some are already generating income while others have just been established. Bee-keeping has been established in all the 7 councils, i.e., Siha, Hai, Moshi District, Moshi Municipality, Mwanga, Rombo, and Same. A total of 44 groups have been formed, i.e., 4 in Siha, Hai (11), Moshi MC (5), Same (4), Mwanga 5, Moshi DC (9), and Rombo (6), with membership varying from 77 in Siha to 252 in Hai, the total being 866. Seven hundred and seventy-four (774) hives have been distributed. To date a total 951 liters of honey has been harvested (350.0 ltrs in Hai), Moshi DC (0), Same 346, Siha 65.8, Mwanga (0) and Rombo 99.5. In terms of income, a total of TZS 9.1 million has been realized as follows: Siha (TZS 0.47); Hai (3.5); Moshi MC (0.9), Moshi DC (0), Rombo (0.99), Mwanga (0), and Same (3.2). To add value to the honey that will be harvested, the Project has bought a honey-processing machine which is being installed at a centre. With regard to poultry, the Project has established a total of 15 poultry groups. In Moshi DC (6), 5 in Rombo, and 4 in Mwanga. Chicken houses have been built, the project will provide chickens (layers), feed, medication, and drinking troughs. Moshi DC and Rombo have made considerable progress in poultry with 303 and 200 birds respectively. So far, Moshi, Rombo and Mwanga districts they have produced 14,700, 2,009, and 790 eggs respectively and sold 13,340, 1,900 and 790 which they have generated TZS 4.0 , 0.47, and TZS 0.22 million respectively. The remaining eggs are being hatched so the pullets can be shared amongst the group members. Regarding mushroom production, the project has worked to establish and develop a mushroom collection and processing centre by engaging into the following: Strengthening Hai Mushroom Growers Association (HAMUG) by facilitating them to undertake registration process which involved technical support to develop a constitution and file application for registration. The organization was registered at district level. 4 meetings were also held to assist the organization develop operating procedure that will ensure them reach better markets and coordinate production and marketing amongst its members; Building capacity of mushroom growers on value addition; provision of equipment including 4 mushroom solar driers and 1 autoclave machine; and Provision of material and technical support for increasing production capacity, e.g., 200 bottles for seed production and Agar solution. The total production of mushroom is 112kg/week, which means 5,824 kg/yr. 243 kg/week of addtional fresh mushroom is dried into is 27.00 kg/week, which 1,404kg/year. Revenue realized is TZS 5,000.00/kg of fresh mushroom generating TZS 29120000.00 per year,while dry mushroom is sold at TZS 60,000.00/kg, realizing TZS 84,240,000.00 per year.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Institutions with capacities to increase knowledge, skills, technologies and change in attitude for adoption and adaptation of SLM

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of people with relevant skills for SLM

baseline.comment: Less than 20% of land users have modern skills for improved management; less than 50% of technical officers have updated SLM skills

target.comment: At least 40% of land users and 30% of technical officers requiring to update skills have done so by mid-term: by the end of project, at least 60% of land users and 75% of technical officers cumulatively have updated skills.

actual.comment: At least 59,237 farmers out of 118,500 (50%) and 265 officers out of 491 (54 %) updated their skills. Results by district are as shown below. Siha District-10,465 (44.4%) out of 23,545 land users have acquired necessary skills on SLM , while 53 (>100%) technical officers out of 13 had updated skills on SLM, Rombo District-713 farmers out of 3858 (18.5%) and 41 technical officers out of 40 (>100%) got skills of SLM (beekeeping, nursery establishment, soil and water conservation structures). Hai District- 63 out of 243 technical officers equivalent to 54 % of officers requiring to update skills have done so, while land users it is 78.8%, i.e., 20,320 out of 25,783 (previus count included outside of catchment, i.e whole district). Moshi District-2,187 land users out of 27,612 (7.9%) and 59 technical staff out 64 (92.1%) in the catchment requiring to update skill have done so. In Moshi MC, 372 farmers out of 602 (61.8%) and 30 out 36 (83.3%) have attained relevant SLM skills. In Mwanga 24,780 out of 35,400 farmers and 25 out of 25 (100%) officers have attained SLM skills. In Same, 400 out of 1700 farmers (23.5%) and 19 out of 30 (63%) officers have attained SLM skills.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Percentage of land and resource users adopting improved practices

baseline.comment: Less than 10% engaging in 1-2 improved practices consistently

target.comment: At least 40% of farmers adopting 3-5 forms of improved practices by mid-term and 50% cumulatively by project end

actual.comment: This target has been achieved, i.e., 50% of land users, i.e., 59,208 out of 118,500 land and resource users have adopted improved practices, such as wood-saving stoves, terracing as a soil and water conservation measure, tree-planting, bee keeping, etc. Siha District- 12,590 (54%) of land users out of 23,545 adopting 3-5 forms of improved practices (terracing, tree planting, river bank protection) Rombo District- 480 out of 3858 (12.4%) engage in improved practices (modern beekeeping, soil and water conservation measures, crop selection and tree planting) in the catchment. Moshi District- 1,053 out of 27,612 (3.8%) participated in rain-water harvesting on farms using a sub-soiling technology, improved poultry management, improved bee-keeping, and tree planting. Hai District- 19,596 out of 25,783 (48600 used previous year was for whole district) equivalent to 76.0 % of land users have adopted 1 forms of improved land-use practices, i.e., tree planting, terracing, and beekeeping. In Moshi MC, 449 out of 602 land users (74.6%), Mwanga 24,780 out of 35,400 (70%), and Same, 260 out of 1,700 (15.3%) land users adopting improved practices.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Knowledge and skills for SLM provided to resource managers at all levels

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Change in agricultural productivity

baseline.comment: Current low and declining, exact levels of selected crops to be obtained during inception

target.comment: At least 20% increase in agricultural produce for key crops for those adopting 3-5 improved practices consistently by mid-term and 50% cumulative by project end

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of farmers using up-to-date weather information in decision making

baseline.comment: Tanzania has relatively good weather data less than 10% of farmers in the Kilimanjaro region use weather data for decision making

target.comment: At least 35% of farmers using up-to-date information from weather stations to determine planting/harvesting dates by mid-term and at least 50% by end of project;

actual.comment: Data collection has just commenced now that the project managed to procure automated weather equipment that has just been installed by the Tanzania Meteorological Agency. To date, Hai has 12,665 households that use weather data for decision making. This section will be updated once all the data has been collected.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Adoption of improved kilns in carbonization

baseline.comment: Less than 10% use improved kilns in carbonization

target.comment: Number of charcoal producers using improved kiln in carbonization in pilot districts increase by at least 30% by mid-term and a cumulative 50% by project end

actual.comment: The regional government in Kilimanjaro outlawed charcoal, implying that it did not want to hear anything about charcoal being made whether efficiently or in a sustainable manner. For the same reason not many people openly to talk about charcoal. However, in June 2015, the project sponsored senior officials of the regional government to attend a workshop on Tree-based bioenergy in Sub-Saharan Africa in Nairobi which discussed opportunities and challenges. Lessons from the workshop may influence how the regional officials now view charcoal. This is especially important because the project has commissioned a study to review policies and regulations on charcoal. However, no matter how positively charcoal may now be perceived, the project has lost an opportunity to improve carbonization by charcoal producers. So, it can only be hoped that such activities will happen at a later stage.

result.title: Objective
result.description: The biodiversity of Southern Tanzania is better represented and buffered from threat within National Parks. (GEF 5.3 mill USD)

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: No net loss of natural habitat in major habitat blocks identified as critical for wildlife dispersal. Two large habitat blocks (Greater Ruaha Landscape and Greater-Kitulo-Kipengere Landscape) are secured with functioning corridors

baseline.comment: Within the GRL, TANAPA have management plans for RUNAPA; WCS and local government supporting development of Mbomipa and Umemaruwa WMAs. In GKKL, KINAPA, MKGR and MRNR have management plans.

target.comment: A working model for integrating management of NPs and wider productive landscapes is operationalised; secures wildlife corridors and dispersal areas covering over 39,000 km2 in the GRL and GKKL ecological landscapes.

actual.comment:
The project collaborated with KNP and Busokelo District Council to introduce a technology on energy-efficient stoves in 10 villages within the council which also border KNP in order to reduce pressure on KNP from the villages for fuel-wood. The 3 PAs were also supported to undertake fair and open processes towards clearing and demarcating their boundaries hence improving relations with their respective neighbouring communities.
Furthermore the project collaborated with KNP and Busokelo District Council to train 46 local artisans from 10 villages in the council which also border KNP, on installation of energy-efficient stoves. This technology is cheap and it is expected that the villages will adopt it easily hence reducing pressure from the villages on fuel-wood from KNP.
The Ruaha Roundtable Forum which brings together researchers from within the project area has continues meeting regularly to share findings, challenges and future plans of the respective researches. Information and experiences shared in this forum are enhancing ecological monitoring and addressing threats to biodiversity within and beyond the project area.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Two national parks (RUNAPA and KNP)and one game reserve (MKGR) have increased operational capacity to manage themselves sustainably

baseline.comment: RUNAPA and KNP lack operational capacity to manage park operations and poaching is common; MKGR is in a vulnerable state of management and all three PAs open to risks of fire and poaching

target.comment: Core NP operations strengthened in Southern Tanzania covering over 22,000 km2 leading to the effective detection and deterrence of poaching and fire risks and improved relationships with adjacent communities.

actual.comment:
The project continued implementing planned activities that focus on achieving integrated management of PAs and the wider landscapes. Operationalization of some of the planned working groups has given strong indication of success.
A range of activities were carried out during the reporting period to increase operational capacity of the three core Protected Areas to manage them sustainably.
The motor grader donated by UNDP through the project to RUNAPA has so far accomplished 952 km of roadwork in the park hence significantly improving mobility and accessibility inside the park. Whereas the three anti-poaching vehicles donated in a similar arrangement to RUNAPA (2) and KNP (1) have maintained good working condition and constantly deployed in the field hence contributing significantly to day-to-day protection activities in the PAs. The project has also facilitated procurement of walking safaris gears for RUNAPA. A state-of-the art digital radio communication system is being installed in RUNAPA and will greatly enhance monitoring of law enforcement and ecology activities when complete.
A consultancy to install a radio collaring and monitoring system for thirty (30) Elephants in the GRL is already on progress. Operationalization of the monitoring system is expected to give important insights into Elephants daily and seasonal activity patterns hence informing future strategies to conserve them and their habitats.
The project has collaborated with TANAPA to set up a GIS Unit at RUNAPA. Thanks to TANAPA hq for committing a full time GIS technician to Ruaha to man the centre. The unit will enhance RUNAPAs and other PAs capacity to collect, store and retrieve data for management use. Staff from RUNAPA, KNP and MKGR was part of the beneficiaries from the GIS and Remote Sensing training organized by the project. These will further facilitate operationalization of the GIS Unit.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: METT scores are improved in the 4 target PAs, especially RUNAPA, KNP and MKGR.

baseline.comment: Current METT scores as follows: RUNAPA (53), KNP (52), MKGR (21), MRNR (40): average: 42

target.comment: RUNAPA and KNP both scoring at least 60. An increase in METT scores in MKGR and MRNR to at least 50; monitoring indicates species diversity either unaffected or increased.

actual.comment: Midterm Review results have revealed significant improvement in METT scores for the 4 target PAs as follows; RUNAPA (66), KNP (61), MKGR (49), MRNR (52). Implying RUNAPA, KNP and MRNR have already surpassed their respective projected end-of-the-project minimum METT scores whereas MKGR has missed out its predetermined end-of-project METT score by 1.

target.comment: x

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Integrating management of NPs and broader landscapes in Southern Tanzania

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Biodiversity management in NPs, GRs, NRs, wildlife migration corridors and dispersal areas is factored into decision-making governing land use management.

baseline.comment: Management activities are carried out on WMA, district, regional government and TANAPA level but with a lack of a landscape level coordination mechanism

target.comment: Inter-sectoral District land management coordination mechanism is emplaced in the GRL and GKKL in Southern Tanzania. Management actions evidenced as a result of decisions and support of landscape level committees and working groups functioning beneath them (land use planning unit, ecological monitoring unit, tourism unit, community conservation unit and enforcement unit)

actual.comment:
The motor grader for RUNAPA by UNDP through the project and has so far accomplished 952 km of roadwork in the park, significantly improving mobility and accessibility inside the park. The three anti-poaching vehicles donated in a similar arrangement to RUNAPA (2) and KNP (1) have continued being in good working condition and constantly deployed in the field hence contributing significantly to day-to-day protection activities in the PAs. The project has also facilitated procurement of walking safaris gears for RUNAPA.
A consultant was also engaged to install state-of-the art digital radio communication system in RUNAPA. Installation progress is beyond 80%. Among other things, the communication system will be allowing proper linkage of ecological management objectives (such as the monitoring movement of radio- collared elephants) and security management objectives (such as monitoring rangers locations and movements from an operational HQ through LCD screen platforms), The communication system includes 15Solar powered digital VHF High power base stations at Ranger posts and Park HQ, 5 Repeaters Units and Six (6) digital VHF High power vehicle radio units with GPS capability installed and operational in six vehicles.
The consultancy to review governance systems and operational practices in the two project landscapes has been completed and the final report shared amongst relevant stakeholders. Recommendations from the consultancy have greatly informed the process towards formation of the Landscape Coordination Committees.
The project is now finalizing the installation of a digital communication system for Law enforcement in the GRL. With digital hand-held radios, VHF High Power Base Stations and LCD screen monitors, the communication system will greatly improve monitoring of law enforcement and ecological activities in the GRL.
Installation of the Elephant Collaring and Monitoring system which is already underway in the GRL is expected to greatly inform future strategies to conserve and monitor the flagship species, other wildlife species and the general habitat.
The project has collaborated with TANAPA to set up a GIS Unit at RUNAPA that will serve southern National Parks and other PAs. Moreover, a tailor-made training on GIS and Remote Sensing was offered to 26 individuals from TANAPA, WD and District Councils who will work closely with the expert manning the GIS unit in RUNAPA.
The project further supported acquisition of a toll-free mobile number from Vodacom-Tanzania 0800751212 through which good the public can report any poaching information/incidence free of charge. The number has been printed on posters and widely disseminated.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Development impacts in sensitive areas have been mitigated, monitoring and reporting systems are in place, and enforcement measures are operational in GRL and GKKL landscapes.

baseline.comment: Monitoring of species and habitats is managed on an individual PA level; understanding of wildlife corridor functions, species movements and dispersal areas limited.

target.comment: A systematic conservation plan for both landscapes that balances biodiversity needs, defines wildlife corridors and dispersal areas, with EIA and M&E systems has been ratified, is in use and is informing measures to address threats to biodiversity in core areas and corridors

actual.comment:
SPANEST Anti poaching campaigns with local artists resulted in composing of 7 songs the on elephant poaching crisis and local tourism promotion.
Official launching of the songs is under way
The project has collaborated with Iringa District Council to organize and facilitate a visit to the northern Tourist circuit in Arusha and Manyara for the representatives from Malinzanga village Maasai women group. The purpose of the mission was mainly for the group members to observe and learn on relevant cultural activities that could be implemented by the women groups in Malinzanga and project area.
The project has received proposal from Iringa district to collaborate in the development of a women cultural centre at Malinzanga on the route to Ruaha Np. The project intends to set aside some funds to develop the centre in collaboration with the women and the district.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Two specialist units are developed by TANAPA with partners; a land use planning unit and an ecological monitoring unit.

baseline.comment: TANAPA has community conservation service and ecology departments in RUNAPA and KINAPA; however lacking adequate coordination functions with external parties.

target.comment: TANAPA has the competence and staff skills to lead land use planning, management and monitoring in landscapes

actual.comment:
The working groups on the themes of Law Enforcement, Tourism, Community Conservation and Ecological Monitoring (Ruaha Roundtable) continued with their respective operations, enhancing cooperation and coordination amongst stakeholders in the project area. These working groups are diverse, with members from TANAPA, WD, TFS, Regional and District authorities, WMAs, Police and the Private Sector. The community Conservation working group for GRL, with members from RUNAPA, SPANEST, WD and District Councils, collaborated with District Defence and Security Committees to conduct conservation awareness campaign in 11 villages aiming at enhancing the understanding of communities on matters related to wildlife conservation and associated potential benefits in order to gain their support in the fight against degradation of natural resources and poaching.
The operational groups on Law Enforcement, Tourism and Community Conservation are already removing barriers between conservation stakeholders in the project landscapes. For instance the Njombe-Iringa-Mbeya Inter Regional Tourism Committee successful managed to mobilize tourism stakeholders from the southern circuit to participate in Karibu Fair staged annually in Arusha as one team for the first time. The team shared a booth hence provided one-stop information centre for Tanzania Southern Tourist Circuit. The Community Conservation Working group in the GRL which is multi-sectoral worked successfully with District Defense and Security committees to promote conservation awareness in 11 villages bordering the GRL.
Tourism Committees for Njombe, Mbeya and Iringa have formed an inter-region tourism committee that is now overseeing tourism related activities beyond the respective regions confines. This umbrella committee managed to mobilize tourism stakeholders from the southern circuit (both public and private) to participate in Karibu Fair that is staged annually in Arusha bringing in tourism stakeholders from all-over the world. The group shared a stand and managed to promote the Southern Circuit collaboratively. The committee is already working to stage southern circuits own fair in Iringa in 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Relations with neighbouring communities to PAs considerably improved: lower instances of human wildlife conflict, fires and poaching

baseline.comment: TANAPA has community conservation service departments in RUNAPA and KINAPA; however park-community relations remain strained in some crucial border areas.

target.comment: TANAPA has a staffed community extension services to ensure effective engagement between communities and park authorities and dispute resolution.

actual.comment:
TANAPA Community relationship continue to be improved through the engagement of the community representatives in common activities such as meetings, visits and consultations.
Project members participated in a number of official meetings organized by MBOMIPA association
SPANEST Project in collaboration with RUNAPA, Pawaga and Idodi Divisions in Iringa district and the Football Association of Iringa district jointly organized football competitions for the youth representing 21 villages bordering Ruaha National Park.
The aim of the competitions named SPANEST Cup is to bring together the majority of youth from the villages to be educated on the escalating elephant poaching in the park and how the youth could be involved in tackling the crisis. The fact that the majority of the members of the community involved in poaching events are the youth, SPANEST thought for a need to ensure
Over 120 matches involving 21 villages, over 250 youth players, have so far participated in the competitions since the launching of the cup in July 2014 to the current stage of final.
Over 150,000 young men and women and other community members from Idodi and Pawaga divisions (21 villages) participated in the matches and were able to receive a message on the current situation of the elephant poaching in Ruaha and how they could participate to stop it.
The number of people who were involved and educated about the elephant poaching crisis during the two months of the campaign was higher than any public gathering event that anyone would organize.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Public consultations are completed in an open and fair manner; beacons mark PA boundaries clearly

baseline.comment: Recent developments in PA status, especially in western Kitulo area, Mpanga Kipengere and Usangu mean boundaries are not clear; conflicts are a result.

target.comment: Agreed boundary beacons are in place around three PAs: RUNAPA, KNP and MKGR, including newly gazetted areas such as Usangu.

actual.comment:
The project support towards clearance of PAs boundary and installing beacons has been participatory and significant. In RUNAPA a boundary stretch of 100 km which is dispute-free is being cleared and will be followed by installation of 100 four-sided beacons. In KNP a boundary conflict with a neighbouring Mpangala village was resolved in an open and fair manner hence enabling proper demarcation of the village-park shared boundary with 20 drum-size beacons. Further 7 beacons have been installed along the shared boundary between KNP and MRNR. In MKGR awareness meetings on boundary demarcation have been convened in 10 neighbouring villages, in collaboration with respective 3 district authorities (including the District Commissioners). The meetings paved way to clearance of a 60 km boundary stretch.
The Project Unit is already working with WD and other stakeholders for best way forward on the matter as directed by the 4th Project Steering Committee.
RUNAPA collaborated with the Project and Mbarali District Council to undertake Land use Plans in three villages within the district which also border RUNAPA.
This was a follow-up initiative to the training on Land Use Planning and Related Laws for PAs and District Councils staff that was funded by SPANEST and conducted by the National Land Use Planning Commission. The exercise aimed to enable the 3 villages to use their land-based resources sustainably hence reducing pressure on the park. The exercise was further an opportunity for the land use planning-trained staff from RUNAPA, SPANEST and KNP to practise their knowledge and skills.
In FY 2015/16 the project has set funds to implement Land Use Plans in 4 villages within Chamwino district in Dodoma region. The villages border GRL hence the expected output will be reduced pressure on the adjacent PAs caused by encroachment and other unsustainable land uses.
In GKKL the project and KNP involved the Makete District Defence and Security Committee to resolve a boundary conflict between KNP and Mpangala village. The conflict was resolved and the share boundary is already permanently demarcated.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Mpanga Kipengere GR is upgraded to NP through consultative process

baseline.comment: Mpanga Kipengere GR is managed on a meagre budget, fires and poaching are rife; tourism is minimal

target.comment: Mpanga Kipengere Game Reserve is raised to higher protected area status as a national park

actual.comment: It was determined to not follow up on the Mpanga Kipengere PA status this year. This was assessed in the MTR.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Bujingijila and Numbe valley corridors gazetted

baseline.comment: Wildlife are not able to move from GRL to GKKL , linkages are weak within GKKL PAs

target.comment: Mpanga Kipengere linked through Numbe valley corridor to Kitulo NP to enable merging the two parks. Bujingijila also allows linkages to Mount Rungwe Nature Reserve

actual.comment:
Bujingijila corridor has been secured following survey results showing that the whole area thought to be Bujingijila corridor actually falls within both KNP and MRNR. The 3.2 km long shared boundary of the two PAs along that area has been permanently demarcated with 7 drum-size beacons.
A preliminary survey on Numbe Valley Corridor was conducted by a team comprising staff from Makete District Council, KNP, MKGR and SPANEST. The preliminary survey outcomes included a proposed course of actions to secure the corridor. The proposed course of actions includes awareness meetings to 3 villages adjacent to Numbe valley, facilitating land use plans in the villages and carryout a physical survey. These are included in the budget for 2015/16.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Operations Support for National Park Management in Southern Tanzania

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Ranger and staff training programme in existence in RUNAPA and KNP; MKGR has joint TANAPA-WD programme; guide training and documentary programmes in existence.

baseline.comment: Rangers have insufficient capacity in RUNAPA, KNP and MKGR to gather intelligence on poaching and fires; relations with tour operators and tourists often strained because of lack of customer care capacity; lack of value-add services.

target.comment: Systematic staff training programme covering all aspects of PA operations ensures 300 rangers, guides and other field staff meet appropriate competencies according to skill set e.g. enforcement, community relations, tourism etc.).

actual.comment:
The project continued to facilitate trainings for PAs staff and other stakeholders geared towards bridging pre-established knowledge and skill gaps.
TANAPA rangers training to develop a Rapid Response Unit for Ruaha National Park rangers which involved three stage training: Selection, Basic, Paramedics, Commanders, and Intensive training. At the end of the training a team of 37 Rangers successfully completed the training aimed to develop and equip them for rapid response to poaching incidences in the Great Ruaha Landscape. The training was conducted by Aegis Defence Services Limited (Aegis), a UK-based company. The Rapid Response Team is already deployed in RUNAPA whereas TANAPA and the project have further strengthened the team by providing them with patrol equipment and f gears.
During the reporting period, a 56 percent decrease of poaching incidences in Ruaha National Park was reported by TANAPA whereby a total of 36 elephants were killed in the year 2013/2014 compared to 82 elephants in the year 2012/2013.
During the same period TANAPA reported on the Improved average time of rangers patrol deployment by 30% and 54% for Ruaha NP and Kitulo NP respectively through patrol vehicles donated by SPANEST project.
Staff from RUNAPA, KNP and MKGR was part of the participants to tailor-made trainings on GIS and Remote Sensing and Open Performance Review and Appraisal (OPRAS). The training on GIS and Remote Sensing was necessary in order to enhance improved collection, storage and analysis of field data in the PAs and across the project landscapes. The Open Performance Review and Appraisal System (OPRAS) are generally accepted as the best appraisal system around in terms of motivating employees and ultimately enhancing efficiency and effectiveness at working stations. Staff from RUNAPA, KNP and MKGR were trained on OPRAS alongside other project stakeholders in order to enhance staff motivation and hence efficiency in the PAs.
The Village Game Scouts for MBOMIPA WMA were supported uniforms and other field gears by the project in order to strengthen security in this PA which borders RUNAPA.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Finance and business planning has established management costs for different PAs and WMAs, and provides accurate revenue forecasts for each PA and the wider landscape (GRL/GKKL) and matches revenue to priority management needs.

baseline.comment: Business planning in southern Tanzania\\\'s PAs lacks local context and full understanding of the international dimension of financial and business planning requirements; business planning is limited a s result.

target.comment: A sustainable finance plan is developed approved and implemented for the PA system in both GRL and GKKL landscapes. Business Planning is mandated for four PAs as well as for two adjacent WMAs, along approved best practice guidelines.

actual.comment:
TARGET EURO Consult was awarded a consultant by UNDP to develop tourism development and Marketing strategy. The consultant has completed the assignment and the strategy is in place and a final draft was shared and presented before key Tourism stakeholders from the Landscapes. The strategy will be used to inform Finance and Business Plans which will be developed in the financial year 2015/2016.
The project along with other stakeholders, supported development of a video documentary for promoting tourist attractions in Makete District and Njombe region.
Another 30minutes documentary featuring project activities since the start of the project was developed and features on Air through a local TV Star TV

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: The input of increased HR capacity and funds for equipment following a business planning approach has lead to greater efficiency and effectiveness of park operations in RUNAPA and KINAPA.

baseline.comment: RUNAPA and KNP lack operational capacity to manage park operations in a sustainable manner , gaps exist in HR across park operations, lack of equipment means difficulty to manage fires, poaching and monitoring the ecosystem.

target.comment: Funds, human resources and equipment are provided and deployed to address threats to RUNAPA and KINAPA in a cost effective manner, utilising business planning - in cooperation with police and judiciary.

actual.comment:
A tailor-made course on Open Performance Review and Appraisal Systems (OPRAS) was facilitated for 17 staff from TANAPA, Tanzania Wildlife Division, Tanzania Forest Services and District Councils. Performance appraisal was one of skills gaps identified within the project area.
50 individuals from public and private sectors were trained on customer care as a way of equipping them to participate in effectively in the service and tourism sectors which hold huge potentials in the southern regions of Tanzania.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Stakeholder groups in both RUNAPA and KNP are engaging positively and constructively on biodiversity management

baseline.comment: There is a marked lack of communication largely due to insufficient funding between different PA authorities, local government, communities, civil society and the private sector, causing inefficiencies, misunderstanding and occasional conflict.

target.comment: A joint (TANAPA-Community-District-Private Sector) stakeholder group formed to address overall intelligence in support of enforcement action both RUNAPA and KNP.

actual.comment:
The project further supported conservation education in 8 villages adjacent to GRL in Chamwino (2) and Manyoni (6) districts which was provided collaboratively by the WD Publicity Unit, RUNAPA, Rungwa/Kizigo/Muhesi and relevant officials from the districts. The Law Enforcement Working Group for the GRL managed to coordinate 2 joint patrols. The fair and open process involving demarcation of PAs boundaries is proving success and is enhancing good relations between the PAs and the adjacent communities. This is important especially now that the project is moving towards creating Landscape Coordination Committees which will be charged with overseeing matters related to land and Natural resources in respective landscapes ; including monitoring the operations of the various work groups. In FY 2015/16 Formation of further two working groups on Land use Planning and Ecological and Water Resources Monitoring will be finalized.
MBOMIPA WMA was facilitated by the project to participate in UNDP Equator Initiative were they won a prize award. Two representatives from the association were also facilitated to attend the award ceremony in Nairobi Kenya.
The project budget for FY 2015/16 also has provision for formulating a joint working group for GRL and GKKL specific for Ecological and Water resources Monitoring. The work group shall be guided by a joint work plan.

iati-activity.description: Mainstreaming Sustainable Forest Management in the Miombo Woodlands of Western Tanzania.

document-link.title: Final SFM Miombo revised and edidted for Signatures after Feedback Mtg in Feb 2012

iati-activity.description: Mainstreaming sustainable forest management in the Miombo woodlands of western Tanzania
